pr_title: Hive ACID row-level insert and delete

timeline.message:
Hive ACID row-level insert and delete

This commit adds support for row-level insert and delete for Hive ACID tables,
and product tests that verify that row-level insert (and delete where allowed)
are working correctly for this test matrix:

(partitioned | unpartitioned) X
(bucketed | unbucketed) X
(normal | insert-only) X
(original files | non-original files) X
(Presto inserts | Hive inserts) X
(first insert | subsequent inserts) X
(Presto deletes | Hive deletes) X
(first delete | subsequent deletes) X
(Hive selects to verify | Presto selects to verify)

The tests also verify that metadata delete still works correctly for non-ACID
tables, and that row-level delete is always used for ACID tables. Hive ACID
insert and delete make metastore updates using the delayed commit paradigm
provided by SemiTransactionalHiveMetastore.

ACID insert and delete need four Hive metastore methods not previously
used, and this commit adds the plumbing through the many metastore layers
for those methods.

Records to be deleted flow through HiveUpdatablePageSource, which feeds an OrcWriter
the three columns - - originalTransaction, bucketId, rowId - - that identify an
ACID row to be deleted. The writer builds the ACID delete_delta bucket, adding
the Orc ACID operation column specifying delete and the currentTransaction column
to each row.

A complete delete scan will in general read many Orc files from earlier transactions.
The delete implementation will create a HiveUpdatablePageSource for each file.
Each will write a delete_delta file, distinguished by different statementIds.
These delete_delta bucket files and directories will be combined by the Hive
ACID compactor as the accumulate.

ACID insert is simpler than delete - - it just adds the 5 ACID columns needed
to make insertion transactional, and creates delta directories to hold bucket files.

timeline.bodyText:
What's the reason to call commit within cleanupQuery?
what if

query is part of a longer transaction (we seem to commit everything too early)
query is cancelled/aborted/etc -- it seems we commit instead of rolling back

please help me understand
